q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This study is a replication of an audit study, which was originally conducted in the United States. Randomly assign elected officials to receive an email from a student seeking more information on a political career. Compare whether legislators are more responsive when the student is male or female.

q16.value: Hypotheses: Gender bias, Within-group, Glass-Ceiling. First, I will estimate the effect of gender on responsiveness. In addition to the gender hypothesis, I will also evaluate whether there are differences for several subgroups: within-group, level of office, party affiliation, region, and age. Quantities of interest to be estimated: Email response (yes/no); Length of response (word count, character count); Type of response: meaningful response, receive praise, receive offer to help, warned against running, received substantive advice, satisfying response.

q17.value: Hypotheses will be tested using differences-in-means and regression analysis that accounts for blocking.

In addition to the gender hypothesis, I will also evaluate whether there are differences for several subgroups: within-group, level of office, party affiliation, region, and age. Quantities of interest to be estimated: Email response (yes/no); Length of response (word count, character count); Type of response: meaningful response, receive praise, receive offer to help, warned against running, received substantive advice, satisfying response.

attributes.title: Exploring Manipulation Checks, Political Knowledge, and Analogies

q1.value: Exploring Manipulation Checks, Political Knowledge, and Analogies

q5.value: Co-PI's include Dr. Jennifer Jerit, Dr. John Kane, Kevin Shan, Benjamin Carter, and Alecia Nepaul

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Broadly, our goal is to study public opinion on several topics, including health care, immigration, and climate change as well as attitudes toward political figures. We also hope to study how opinions and attitudes change with the provision of information to some randomly selected respondents. Finally, we wish to explore methods used to measure attentiveness in survey experiments. This multi-investigator study features common pre-treatment and post-treatment survey question batteries that bracket several distinct experiment modules on (1) manipulation checks, (2) political knowledge, and (3) analogies. The order of the experiments will be varied randomly across subsets of respondents in a manner described later. Subsets of the team will be involved with some modules but not necessarily all others.

q17.value: We will conduct analyses: • Descriptive statistics of sample across demographic and political characteristics. We will compare our samples with other population or national survey benchmarks. • Balance tests to demonstrate that assignment to treatment was random. • Difference of means (or proportions when appropriate) across the treatment and control groups assuming unequal variances. • Non-parametric tests (e.g., Fisher’s exact tests). • Statistical analyses via regression or similar maximum likelihood estimators depending on the structure of the dependent variable with dummy variables for treatment groups as well as models with treatment groups with socio-demographic control variables. • Estimation of heterogeneous treatment effects related to socio-demographic predictors as well as passage of any of the many forms of manipulation checks in the study. Similar analyses for those who learn or respond to the analogies. • We intend to explore complier average treatment effects as well as mediational relationships, subject to assumptions regarding exclusion restrictions and sequential ignorability, using instrumental variable estimators (e.g., Angrist et al. 1996; Gerber and Green 2000; 2012; Greene 2012; Wooldridge 2013) and causal mediation approaches (Imai et al. 2011). The survey experiments on manipulation checks, political information, and analogies were all designed with the possibility of combining conditions. If conditions are not significantly different (i.e., p >. .05, two-tailed, conditional on successful balance of pre-treatment covariates via model chi-square of p > .05), they will be available for combined analysis to increase the statistical power of the study.

attributes.title: Public Opinion and Crisis Behavior in a Nuclearized South Asia

q1.value: Public Opinion and Crisis Behavior in a Nuclearized South Asia

q2.value: Christopher Clary | Sameer Lalwani | Niloufer Siddiqui

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Can leaders in India and Pakistan back down in a crisis without suffering substantial public sanction? If leaders are fearful that compromise or inaction in a crisis will be met by public anger, they may opt to pursue a military policy more confrontational and dangerous than they would otherwise desire. This may make conflict more likely than would be the case where the public was prudent and conflict-averse.

q16.value: We propose to test how public opinion shapes crisis behavior in South Asia through a combination of traditional survey questions and survey experimental techniques. We propose a series of experiments to determine whether and to what extent: • respondents decrease their support for a political leader when the leader de-escalates compared to when s/he chooses to respond in an escalatory fashion; • support for such decisions differs depending on if a civilian or military leader is stated to have taken the de-/escalatory decision; and • respondents base their preference on the potential justifications that leaders make to explain their de-escalation. In particular, we are interested in knowing whether references to nuclear dangers or potential economic costs decrease any punishment respondents impose upon de-escalating leaders.

q17.value: Difference-in-means, ANOVA and Wilcoxon rank sum tests for ordinal outcomes.

In particular, we are interested in knowing whether references to nuclear dangers or potential economic costs decrease any punishment respondents impose upon de-escalating leaders.

q5.value: The author is grateful to LORE for providing the infrastructure for implementing this experiment, and in particular to Elina Lindgren and Johan Martinsson for their crucial help in designing this experiment., Many thanks are also due to my supervisors, Elin Naurin and Maria Oskarson, as well as to Ruth Dassonneville, Jacob Sohlberg, Mike Tomz, Endre Tvinnereim, and Peter Esaiasson for their invaluable input during various stages of this project., Finally, the author wishes to express his gratitude to the department of Political Science, and the SOM Institute for making this research possible.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Election pledges arguably take an important role in influential theoretical accounts of representative democracy. Through election pledges, voters can familiarise themselves with the policy plans of prospective representatives and base their vote choice on the extent of congruence between the presented agendas and their own policy preferences. In addition, the level of fulfilment of election pledges can function as a shortcut for voters to monitor the performance of elected representatives, and therewith fuel accountability processes. Empirical work in this area, however, has thus-far almost exclusively focused on the extent to which politicians and political parties fulfil their election pledges. How fulfilled and broken election pledges affect voters has received far less empirical attention. My thesis aims to bridge that gap, hypothesising that all else equal, breaking election pledges leads to lower government approval, while fulfilling pledges leads to higher government approval. The particular study proposal outlined here aims to investigate the conditionality of the effect of broken and fulfilled election pledges on voters’ approval of government performance, upon their prior expectations of election pledge fulfilment.

q16.value: It is hypothesised that voters with low expectations are more (positively) affected by fulfilled election pledges than voters with high expectations, and that voters with high expectations are more (negatively) affected by broken election pledges than voters with low expectations. The central dependent variable of the study is voter approval of the performance of the main government party in Sweden, the Social Democrats. Potential effects on vote intention are also recorded.

q17.value: The experiment is embedded in a wave of the Swedish Citizen Panel, run by the Laboratory of Opinion Research (LORE) at the University of Gothenburg in Sweden. First, a pre-measure of the central dependent variable (Social Democrat approval) is provided through a survey instrument that separately the respondents’ opinion about the performance of both current government parties, and the current opposition parties. Then, 40% of the respondents (groups 1 & 2) receive a treatment text intended to raise their pledge fulfilment expectations. Another 40% (groups 3 & 4) receive a treatment text intended to lower their fulfilment expectations. The remaining 20%, in the control group, receive a null treatment text including the same key words. As a manipulation check, all respondents are asked to state their pledge fulfilment expectations after treatment. In the third step, 40% of the respondents (groups 1 & 3) receive a treatment text highlighting the Social Democrats’ fulfilled election pledges. Another 40% (groups 2 & 4) receive a treatment text highlighting the Social Democrats’ broken election pledges. The remaining 20% in the control group receive a null treatment text containing the same key words, but merely highlighting the election pledges that the Social Democrats made. Now, for group 1, the raised fulfilment expectations should have been positively confirmed; for group 2, the raised fulfilment expectations should have been negatively disconfirmed; for group 3, the lowered fulfilment expectations should have been positively disconfirmed, and for group 4, the lowered fulflment expectations should have been negatively confirmed. The efficacy of the (dis)confirmation treatments is additionally assessed through a mediator implemented immediately after the dependent variables. Three questions constitute the dependent variables of this study. First, the central dependent variable (Social Democrat approval) is measured for the second time. Secondly, the respondents are asked how likely it is that they would vote for the Social Democrats if elections were held today. Finally, the respondents are asked which party they would vote for if elections were held today. After these questions, the mediator is posed, asking respondents whether they feel th Social Democrats generally fulfil most of their election pledges. Finally, a policy preference instrument is posed as a control. Other potential controls include partisanship, political trust, political interest, sex, age, and education level. The hetereogeneity of the effects will be explored. Preliminarily, the expectations are that respondents with stronger partisan attachments, higher political interest, and higher education levels will be less affected by the (dis)confirmation effects. A copy of the concrete experimental design, translated to English from the original Swedish, is attached.

registration_responses.q5: The author is grateful to LORE for providing the infrastructure for implementing this experiment, and in particular to Elina Lindgren and Johan Martinsson for their crucial help in designing this experiment., Many thanks are also due to my supervisors, Elin Naurin and Maria Oskarson, as well as to Ruth Dassonneville, Jacob Sohlberg, Mike Tomz, Endre Tvinnereim, and Peter Esaiasson for their invaluable input during various stages of this project., Finally, the author wishes to express his gratitude to the department of Political Science, and the SOM Institute for making this research possible.

attributes.title: The Media Matters: Muslim American Portrayals and the Effects on Mass Attitudes

q1.value: The Media Matters: Muslim American Portrayals and the Effects on Mass Attitudes

q5.value: I am grateful to Marisa Abrajano, Daniella Bardalez, Taylor Carlson, Stephanie DeMora, Valerie Martinez Ebers, Karen Ferree, James Fowler, Zoli Hajnal, Seth Hill, Paul Kellstedt, John Kuk, Katerina Schenke, Annelise Sklar, Liesel Spangler, and Dave Vidmar for their detailed feedback on this project at multiple stages.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Previous theories have argued that the news media is an important conduit for conveying messages to the public (Chomsky, 1997; Markham and Maslog, 1971). It shapes attitudes, influences the national discourse, and generates stereotypes (Brummett, 2014). Prior studies have found that the news media tends to portray minorities as troublesome constituents (Abrajano and Singh, 2009; Baum, 2003; Branton and Dunaway, 2008; Entman, 1990; Gilliam Jr and Iyengar, 2000; Gilliam Jr et al., 1996; Iyengar, Peters and Kinder, 1982; Kellstedt, 2003, 2005; Prior, 2005; Wortley, Hagan and Macmillan, 1997). Past research also suggests that the ways in which outgroups are represented in media impacts the public’s perceptions, attitudes, and behaviors towards members of those outgroups (Harwood et al., 2012; Haynes, Merolla and Ramakrishnan, 2016; Mastro, 2009; Merolla, Ramakrishnan and Haynes, 2013; Saleem, Yang and Ramasubramanian, 2016), and shapes support for policies that harm members of the depicted outgroup (Mastro and Kopacz, 2006; Ramasubramanian, 2011). Given that Arabs, Middle Easterners, and foreign Muslims are frequently linked with tropes of violence, terrorism, and aggression across American media outlets (Alsultany, 2012; Nacos, 2016; Nacos and Torres-Reyna, 2002, 2007), one should expect these findings to extend to American Muslims. Media portrayals of Middle Easterners, for instance, have long been related to narratives of terrorism, violence, threat, and fear (see Behm-Morawitz and Ortiz (2013); Esposito (1999); Gadarian (2010); GhaneaBassiri (2013); Said (1979); Selod (2015a); Shaheen (2003); Steet (2000); Wilkins (1995)). My own scholarship has yielded three important takeaways demonstrating that news media coverage of Muslim Americans is largely negative. First, the news media communicated Muslim Americans more negatively than other racialized American groups across CNN, FOX, and MSNBC news broadcast platforms, in both the pre- and post-9/11 periods. Second, the ideology of the publication platform matters for how negatively a given network discusses marginalized groups. While FOX consistently discussed all groups negatively, MSNBC appears to have discussed Blacks, Latinos, and Asian Americans more positively in the pre-and post-9/11 periods. Finally, no network treated Muslim Americans similarly to other racialized groups. Rather, each network in each time period (pre- and post-9/11) discussed Muslim Americans more negatively than the other examined groups. As a result, Muslim Americans appear to not be able to reach American viewers in a positive light, even when compared to other racialized groups, who we know through prior scholarship are communicated negatively to begin with. What remains unknown is whether media coverage about Muslims (foreign group) and Muslim Americans (domestic group) shape attitudes towards the domestic group and affect attitudes towards policies affecting them. In this study, I refine and build on several previous experiments that I employed for my dissertation (2017), and explore whether exposure to negative versus positive media coverage about Muslims and Muslim Americans matters for public attitudes. Previously my studies have employed a within-subject design when assessing how exposure to media coverage affects attitudes towards the group and a between-subject design when assessing how exposure to media coverage affects attitudes towards policies affecting the foreign and domestic groups. Currently, I am refining the study and re-conducting these experiments. Specifically, I am removing the within-subject design when assessing attitudes towards the group to ensure that questions priming attitudes towards Muslims are removed. Moreover, I include several additional treatments beyond positive and negative transcripts about Muslims (foreign) and Muslim Americans (domestic). Specifically, I have positive and negative frames about immigrants and Latinos in order to ensure that it is not just exposure to any positive or negative information about marginalized groups that causes shifts in attitudes towards Muslims foreign and domestic. Rather, these conditions aim to demonstrate shifts in attitudes about Muslims are specific to broadcasts about Muslims themselves. In this study, I also employ a control group. The current study begins first with a consent form. Respondents are then randomized into 1 of 10 conditions (Muslim American positive, Muslim American (alternative – treatment not about terrorism), Muslim positive, Muslim negative, Immigrant positive, Immigrant negative, Latino positive, Latino negative, and Control). They are then asked the policy DVs and the attitudinal questions through the Muslim American Resentment scale (Lajevardi 2017, Lajevardi and Abrajano 2019). After answering these questions, they are asked a series of demographic and partisanship questions.

q16.value: H1: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims and Muslim Americans. H1a: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans. H1b: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims. H2: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims and Muslim Americans. H2a: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans. H2b: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims. H3: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H3a: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H3b: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H4: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H4a: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H4b: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H5: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H5a: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H5b: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H6: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H6a: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H6b: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H7: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Latinos compared to those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Latinos. H8: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about immigrants compared to those respondents who were exposed to negative information about immigrants. H9: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans (alternative) treatment. H10: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans (alternative) treatment.

q17.value: To assess these hypotheses, I will contract with Lucid, a survey company which will field my experiment. The study will be hosted on Qualtrics and survey respondents from Lucid will be directed towards the Qualtrics study and complete the questionnaire on that platform.

q27.value: Lucid, a survey company, will survey respondents on my behalf.

H1b: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims. H2: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims and Muslim Americans. H2a: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans. H2b: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims. H3: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H3a: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H3b: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H4: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H4a: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H4b: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will be more negative among those respondents who were exposed to negative information Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H5: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H5a: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H5b: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H6: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims and Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H6a: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H6b: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslims compared to those respondents who were exposed to the control group. H7: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Latinos compared to those respondents who were exposed to negative information about Latinos. H8: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about immigrants compared to those respondents who were exposed to negative information about immigrants. H9: Attitudes towards Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans (alternative) treatment. H10: Attitudes towards policies affecting Muslims and Muslim Americans will not significantly differ among those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans compared to those respondents who were exposed to positive information about Muslim Americans (alternative) treatment.
registration_responses.q17: To assess these hypotheses, I will contract with Lucid, a survey company which will field my experiment. The study will be hosted on Qualtrics and survey respondents from Lucid will be directed towards the Qualtrics study and complete the questionnaire on that platform.
registration_responses.q27: Lucid, a survey company, will survey respondents on my behalf.

attributes.title: Pre-Analysis Plan: Identifying and Mitigating Sources of Tension between Jordanians and Syrian Refugees

q1.value: Pre-Analysis Plan: Identifying and Mitigating Sources of Tension between Jordanians and Syrian Refugees

q2.value: Dominik Hangartner | Ala' Alrababa'h | Andrea Dillon | Scott Williamson | Jens Hainmueller | Duncan Lawrence | Jeremy Weinstein

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Jordan currently hosts over 1 million Syrians, and while Jordan has a long history of welcoming refugees, the record-high number of Syrians has strained the country's limited resources and generated tensions between host communities and the refugee population. Against this background, this project focuses on two major questions: (1) What factors drive the formation of attitudes toward vulnerable refugee populations? and (2) How can attitudes toward refugees be influenced or changed? We examine these questions by leveraging a nationally representative survey of Jordanian citizens.

q16.value: To understand the factors shaping attitudes toward refugees, we first conduct a conjoint analysis with the goal of identifying how the dierent characteristics of refugees shape the willingness of Jordanians to welcome Syrians into the country. In particular, we seek to understand the extent to which Jordanians' attitudes are shaped by perceptions of economic, cultural, security, and humanitarian concerns. Second, we examine a series of mechanisms for promoting generosity - awareness of need, highlighting the joy of giving, making salient shared cultural values - through experimental manipulations and a subsequent measurement of respondents' perceptions of refugees, attitudes on refugee-related policies, and behavioral measures of generosity both immediately after the survey and one week later.

q17.value: The first part focused on understanding the factors shaping attitudes toward refugees and will rely on series of conjoint tasks embedded in a survey experiment. The second party focused on attitudinal change will rely on three randomized video treatments that highlight i) awareness of need, ii) the joy of giving, iii) and make salient shared cultural values between Jordanian natives and Syrian refugees.

registration_responses.q1: Pre-Analysis Plan: Identifying and Mitigating Sources of Tension between Jordanians and Syrian Refugees
registration_responses.q2: Dominik Hangartner | Ala' Alrababa'h | Andrea Dillon | Scott Williamson | Jens Hainmueller | Duncan Lawrence | Jeremy Weinstein

The second party focused on attitudinal change will rely on three randomized video treatments that highlight i) awareness of need, ii) the joy of giving, iii) and make salient shared cultural values between Jordanian natives and Syrian refugees.

attributes.title: Attitudes towards democracy and ideology. What explains the decline in satisfaction with democracy?

q1.value: Attitudes towards democracy and ideology. What explains the decline in satisfaction with democracy?

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: While research in the relationship between left-right positions and vote is bountiful, the impact of ideology on attitudes towards democracy has been understudied when not ignored. If citizens’ ideological self-placement determines the political choices they make, whether they decide to vote or abstain in an election or even the issues that are relevant for them in taking these decisions, would not be expected left-right orientations to be associated to the attitudes towards the political regime? In addition, ideology is the basic template to understand events and make political assessments, so it should have an impact on the information we weight more to assess the political regime. We should expect citizens on different sides of the ideological scale to evaluate their satisfaction with the political system under different terms. In this paper we explore this moderating effect of ideology by looking to satisfaction with democracy, as this is one of the main attitudinal variables that we should pay attention to in democratic systems. Just recently, Besir Ceka and Pedro C. Magalhães (2016) briefly explored the way left-right orientations are related to different conceptualizations of democracy. They found that those on the left side of the ideological continuum are more prone than rightists to emphasize social justice and redistribution as key elements for democracy. Even more, right wingers are significantly less demanding in their concept of democracy. Taking this empirical evidence into account, leftists and rightists would have different expectations about what a democracy is and what outcomes it should deliver. Thus, their satisfaction with democracy would be shaped by different factors. If these expectations are confirmed, it can be said that those on the left are more worried about the quality of their democracy in terms of how it represents different views and provides equality for all citizens. The right, as it is less demanding with the inputs of the system and tends to be always more satisfied with democracy than the exigent left, would be more satisfied when the perceived outcomes produced by the democratic system are positive. Thus, while leftists would worry about how the democracy should be and work, rightists would focus on whether the products resulting of it. As the more evident outputs would be economic ones, rightists that perceive the economy to be good would more satisfied with democracy than rightists living in a country going through economic hardship.

q16.value: Negative information on the political inputs of democracy in a country would have a more negative impact on the satisfaction with democracy for those on the left more than those on the right. Negative information on the economic outputs of democracy in a country would have a more negative impact on the satisfaction with democracy for those on the right more than those on the left.

registration_responses.q1: Attitudes towards democracy and ideology. What explains the decline in satisfaction with democracy?
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

In addition, ideology is the basic template to understand events and make political assessments, so it should have an impact on the information we weight more to assess the political regime. attributes.title: Does Public Opinion Affect Elite Speech? Predicting Sentiment Using Machine Learning Techniques

q1.value: Does Public Opinion Affect Elite Speech? Predicting Sentiment Using Machine Learning Techniques

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We propose and pre-specify a procedure to measure substantial agreement between elite speech and public opinion. Briefly put, the procedure can be described as follows: In a first step, we select a small subset of the elite speech and public opinion data. We then manually code substantial agreement for this subset of the data. In a second step, we use this subset as the training set for an automated prediction algorithm using machine learning methods. We aim to predict substantial agreement for all remaining observations based on the hand-coded observations. Using the automated prediction, we then run a regression discontinuity procedure comparing elite speech to public opinion.

q16.value: We do not test a hypothesis.

q17.value: We do not test any hypotheses.

registration_responses.q1: Does Public Opinion Affect Elite Speech? Predicting Sentiment Using Machine Learning Techniques

attributes.title: The Political Economy of AI-driven Automation

q1.value: The Political Economy of AI-driven Automation

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In recent decades the automation of work has disproportionately benefitted highly educated workers and capital owners while moderately educated workers have seen their wages and job security decline (Autor and Salomons, 2018; Van Reenen, 2011). As a result, economic inequality between workers has grown (Van Reenen, 2011), labour markets have polarised into “lousy and lovely jobs” (Goos and Manning, 2007), and the labour share has declined (Karabarbounis and Neiman, 2014). In response to predictions that between 9% and 35% of UK workers will be displaced by automation in the coming ten to twenty years (Arntz et al., 2016; Frey et al., 2016), commentators have proposed a range of innovative policies to mitigate further growth in inequality. Proposals include novel forms of taxation (Geoffard, 2016), provision of a universal basic income (Brynjolfsson and McAfee, 2014; Reed and Lansley, 2016; Srnicek and Williams, 2015), or public provision of services, from transport to housing (Portes, 2017). However, it is not clear whether such policies could win popular support as the effects automation are increasingly felt by voters, paticularly given rightward-shift in policy preferences witnessed in recent years (e.g. Anelli et al., 2019; Dal Bo et al., 2019; Frey et al., 2018). Using an online survey experiment (n = 2,500) I therefore investigate how informing UK adults about their potential vulnerability to a labour market shock resulting from automation influences their preferences for a range of policies. I also test whether presenting rhetoric designed to challenge existing narratives conditions this effect and investigate possible explanatory mechanisms.

q16.value: H1: Informing individuals about their potential vulnerability to a labour market shock (T1) will: a) reduce support for policies intended to provide financial support to those who are least well-off; namely, increasing income support and unemployment benefit; b) reduce support for policies that increase taxes on corporations’ profits and high-earning individuals’ incomes; and c) increase support for policies intended to limit immigration. H2: Rhetoric designed to challenge the effect of existing media narratives on individuals’ preferences (T2) will reverse some, or all, of the shift in preferences resulting from exposure to an economic shock (T1). In other words, exposure to T2 will: a) increase support for policies intended to provide financial support to those who are least well-off, such as increasing income support and unemployment benefit; b) increase support for policies that increase taxes on corporations’ profits and high-earning individuals’ incomes; and c) reduce support for policies intended to limit immigration.

q17.value: Respondents will be randomly assigned to read a short, newspaper-style passage about the possible negative labour market impacts of an automation shock, alongside either: (i) a policy-neutral statement about the possible societal implications of the shock (T1); or (ii) rhetoric designed to challenge existing narratives about the possible societal implications of such a shock (T2). A control group will be assigned to read a passage that describes changes in the types of occupations that workers have been employed in during recent decades, without mentioning the possibility of any negative labour market effects (Control). The Control passage is intended to have a neutral effect on the dependent variables under consideration. To increase engagement with the treatment, respondents will be asked whether they know anyone employed in the occupations mentioned in the respective passages. Respondents will then be asked about their preferences regarding a range of policies that could be adopted in the UK in the coming decades. Regression analyses will be used to estimate the effect of treatment (relative to the control) on individuals’ policy preferences. Respondents will also be asked a series of questions about their expectations and experiences, in order to test which mechanisms underpin any shift in policy preferences. Please see the accompanying pre-analysis plan for details of the empirical strategy.
